measured_by: non-decision time (t0) parameter of the Diffusion Decision Model
justification: “In cueing paradigms, we interpret this parameter as being sensitive to attention orienting effects for cued versus miscued trials…and recognise it is indexing the time course of attentional selection.”

measured_by: starting point (z) parameter of the Diffusion Decision Model
justification: The paper notes that a “very brief burst of information processing resources to the cued location…would be characterised as a shift in the start-point of regular evidence accumulation,” identifying starting point as the marker of this mechanism.

measured_by: drift rate (v) parameter of the Diffusion Decision Model
justification: “Drift rate corresponds to the overall quality of evidence…According to a drift rate account of gaze cueing, information processing resources are preferentially allocated to the cued location.”

measured_by: gaze-cueing paradigm (response-time difference between cued and miscued trials)
justification: “Empirically, the gaze cueing effect has been demonstrated using the gaze cueing paradigm…The gaze cueing effect describes the typical finding that faster mean response times arise for cued versus miscued trials.”
